A new boron modified carbon nitride metal-free catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 and bisepoxides Yuanping Zhang Writing – original draft Methodology Investigation Formal analysis Data curation a b Qin Wang Writing – review & editing a b Qian Chen Writing – review & editing a b Xiaoyun Li Writing – review & editing Visualization Funding acquisition a Yanfang Li Writing – review & editing c Maoqing Kang Supervision Resources Formal analysis a Qifeng Li Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Formal analysis a ⁎ Junwei Wang Writing – review & editing Supervision Resources Investigation Conceptualization a ⁎ a Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan, Shanxi 030001, PR China Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences Taiyuan Shanxi 030001 PR China Institute of Coal Chemistry, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Taiyuan 030001, Shanxi, PR China b University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences Beijing 100049 PR China University of Chinese Academy of Sciences, Beijing 100049, PR China c Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lyuliang University, Lyuliang, Shanxi 033001, PR China Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lyuliang University Lyuliang Shanxi 033001 PR China Department of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lyuliang University, Lyuliang 033001, Shanxi, PR China ⁎ Corresponding authors. The cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide is regarded as an eco-friendly, sustainable, and promising way to utilize CO2. However, it is crucial to design and prepare efficient and low-cost catalysts for this reaction. Herein, through controlling condensation temperature, a series of boron modified urea-derived g-C3N4 (x-BCN) were prepared. Notably, more edge defect (−NH2/−NH−) formed at low roasting temperatures and both basic and acidic sites increased after introducing B. 0.30-BCN exhibited superior catalytic performance for cycloaddition of CO2 with 1, 4-butanediol diglycidyl ether and 99% cyclic carbonate yield was acquired at 130 ℃, 2.0 MPa after 20 h reacting. Additionally, 0.30-BCN showed outstanding recyclability and substrate adaptability. The synergistic effects of edge defects, rich mesoporous structure and Lewis acid-base sites were conductive to promoting CO2 cycloaddition. Moreover, a possible multi-synergetic mechanism was proposed. An originality option was provided for preparing a simple, eco-friendly, and efficient metal-free catalyst for practical CO2 fixation. Graphical Abstract Keywords Urea-derived carbon nitride Low polymerization degree Boron modification Acid-base duality CO2 cycloaddition Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The greenhouse effect caused by excessive carbon dioxide (CO2) emissions has triggered a series of severe negative impacts, including global warming, glacier melting, ocean acidification, and extreme weather events [1,2]. Meanwhile, CO2 is also an abundant, non-toxic, and sustainable C1 resource for synthesis of high value-added chemicals such as urea, methane, methanol, formic acid, organic/inorganic carbonates [3–7]. Among them, the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides into cyclic carbonates is one of the simplest and most atomic efficient path for CO2 utilization, and it also fully conforms to the concept of green chemistry. Furthermore, cyclic carbonate is widely used in polar aprotic solvents, electrolytes for Li-ion batteries, polycarbonate monomers, medical intermediates, and so on [8–11]. Due to the thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness of CO2 [8,12], it is necessary to find efficient catalysts that can break high reaction barriers of CO2 cycloaddition reaction. Previous literature pointed out that ring-opening of epoxide is the rate-determining step in CO2 cycloaddition [13]. In general, metal ions and hydrogen bond donors (HBDs) can be used to activate epoxides. Metal ions can be used to activate epoxides as Lewis acids by forming metal−O coordination bonds, while HBDs can polarize the C−O bonds of epoxides via forming hydrogen bonds with O of epoxides. Based on these, a variety of homogeneous and heterogeneous catalysts have been developed, such as metallic oxides [14,15], ionic liquids [16,17], HBDs complex [18,19], metal-organic framework (MOFs) [20,21], and functional polymers, etc. [22,23]. While improving the catalytic performance, these catalysts also have some drawbacks such as difficult product separation and purification, complex catalyst synthesis route, metal leaching and environmental pollution. Besides, most catalysts currently target the reaction of small mono-epoxides with CO2. In the case of CO2 cycloaddition for epoxides containing two or more epoxy groups, relatively few studies on the utilization of catalysts have been reported. Moreover, difunctional or polyfunctional cyclic carbonates can serve as precursors for highly potential chemicals, such as non-isocyanate polyurethanes [24,25]. It is known that larger epoxide molecules intrinsically have higher steric demand, and the physical properties of molecules of different sizes (such as viscosity) also vary greatly, making the cycloaddition of CO2 to high molecule weight epoxides challenging. Therefore, it is meaningful to develop a metal-free heterogeneous catalyst with simple preparation, low cost and high efficiency for the cycloaddition reaction between CO2 and polyfunctional epoxides (such as 1, 4-butanediol diglycidyl ether). Graphite carbon nitride (g-C3N4), a metal-free heterogeneous catalyst, aroused extensive attention in CO2 cycloaddition due to its preparation simplicity, high thermal and chemical stability, eco-friendliness, and nitrogen-rich structure. In particular, rich amine groups (such as tri-s-triazine ring, −NH2, and −NH−) on the surface of g-C3N4 can be used to adsorb and activate CO2 as Lewis base sites [26,27], and these uncondensed amines (−NH2 and −NH−) can also activate partly epoxide through hydrogen bonding [28,29]. Additionally, in the process of synthesizing g-C3N4 by thermal condensation polymerization, intermediates with different degrees of condensation such as melem are successively produced ( Scheme 1). Interestingly, these intermediates have different catalytic activities, and more terminal defective structures are conducive to CO2 cycloaddition reactions. Unfortunately, the original CN provided poor activity owing to its low specificity and absence of active sites that can activate epoxide. Hence, a series of strategies (including increasing surface area, element doping, and so on) to modify g-C3N4 were developed to further improve the catalytic performance. Currently, various modified g-C3N4 catalysts such as mesoporous mp-CN-450 [30], the exfoliation of CN [31], SBA-15 loaded CN [32], metal halides supported CN [33], have been reported in the CO2 cycloaddition. The results proved that the modified CN significantly improved the catalytic activity. Su et al. [34] reported the urea-derived g-C3N4 (u-g-C3N4) prepared at different temperatures could catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reaction with 67.2% propylene carbonate (PC) yield under 130 ℃, 2.0 MPa for 8 h. It demonstrated that lower polymerization degree and a larger number of macropores were obtained as the preparation temperature decreased, which exposed more edge defects, resulting in better catalytic performance. Zhu et al. [32] reported that B-doped carbon nitride (B-CN) loaded on SBA-15 catalyzed the CO2 cycloaddition reaction with 94.7% styrene carbonate (SC) yield under 130 °C, 3.0 MPa for 24 h. The improvement of B-CN catalytic activity was mainly attributed to the increase of both surface basic and acid sites of g-C3N4 after doping of B atoms. However, harsher reaction conditions are still required, and some of them require solvents or co-catalysts to improve the catalytic activity. Considering the above principles, a series of metal-free boron modified g-C3N4 with acid-base duality (x-BCN) were successfully developed using urea as precursor and boric acid as B source at 450 ℃. The effects of different B amounts on the crystallinity, polymerization degree, species and positions of active groups, and quantities of edge defects of the sample were investigated. Moreover, according to XPS and elemental analysis characterization, the insertion sites of B and the influence of B introduction on different N-containing groups in the catalyst structure were further confirmed. Subsequently, the x-BCN as catalysts were used for the cycloaddition of CO2 and 1, 4-Butanediol diglycidyl ether (BDODGE) without co-catalyst and solvent, and the catalytic behaviors were briefly studied. Ultimately, a multi-synergetic mechanism of the catalytic cycloaddition was proposed. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation The urea-derived carbon nitride was synthesized using the previously reported method [34]. Typically, 10 g of urea was poured into a covered crucible and heated to 450 ℃ for 4 h in a muffle furnace with a heating rate of 5 ℃ min−1. The obtained yellow solid product was ground to a fine powder for further use. The obtained urea-derived carbon nitride catalyst was marked as CN. A series of B modified carbon nitride catalysts with varied boron amounts were prepared according to the literature [35]. Typically, 5 g of urea and a certain amount of H3BO3 were mixed in deionized water and treated through ultrasonic treatment for 30 min. The obtained solution was heated to 80 °C on magnetic stirring until water was completely evaporated. Thereafter, the final mixture was transferred into a muffle furnace and calcined in air at 450 ℃ for 4 h. Through the above steps, a series of x-BCN catalysts with different H3BO3/Urea mass ratios (x = 0.01, 0.05, 0.10, 0.15, 0.20, 0.25, 0.30, 0.35) were prepared (x represents the boron weight percentage). The preparation process of the catalysts is shown in Scheme 2. 2.2 Characterization The crystal structures of the samples were characterized by using X-ray diffraction (XRD) measurements on a Bruker D8 Advance X-ray diffractometer with Cu Kα (λ= 1.54 Å) irradiation. The Fourier-transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were collected on the Nicolet iS20 FT-IR instrument. The elemental composition and chemical states were obtained using X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurement and recorded on an AXIS ULTRA DLD spectrometer. Elemental analysis (EA) was used to determine the content of H, C, N, and O in the sample with a Vario EL CUBE instrument. The surface morphology and element distribution of the samples were investigated using scanning electronic micrograph (SEM, JSM-7001 F). Nitrogen adsorption-desorption isotherms were conducted on the Tristar II 3020 measurement at liquid nitrogen temperature. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was recorded on the TGA-50 instrument. The samples were heated from room temperature to 800 ℃ at a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1 under N2 atmosphere with a flow rate of 30 mL min−1. The temperature programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were measured using a BELCAT-B instrument equipped with a thermal conductivity detector (TCD) detector. The TPD measurements were carried out the temperature range of 30−450 ℃ with a heating rate of 10 ℃ min−1. 1H NMR spectra were taken by using Bruker AVANCE Ⅲ (400 MHz) spectrometer using CDCl3 as the solvent and toluene as an internal standard. 2.3 Synthesis of five-membered cyclocarbonates (5CC) The 1, 4-butanediol diglycidyl ether cyclic carbonate (BDODGE-5CC), hereafter this cyclocarbonate being abbreviated as 5CC, was synthesized by BDODGE with CO2 to evaluate the catalytic performance of the prepared catalysts. Firstly, 1.5 g catalyst and 30.0 g BDODGE were introduced into a 100 mL stainless steel autoclave equipped with a magnetic stirrer. The reactor was purged with N2 for three times and heated to 130 ℃. Thereafter, the autoclave was pressurized with CO2 to 2.0 MPa and maintained for 20 h under stirring. Finally, the reactor was cooled to room temperature and the mixture was separated via filtration and centrifugation. The conversion of BDODGE and selectivity of corresponding cyclic carbonate were calculated from the 1H NMR spectra of the product [36], and the 1H NMR spectra of all epoxides and cyclic carbonates used in this work were exhibited in Fig. S6-12. (Details are shown in Supplementary Information). 3 Results and discussions 3.1 Compositional and structural studies The structural investigations of x-BCN were carried out using powder XRD measurements, and the patterns are presented in Fig. 1(a). The XRD pattern of CN was added as a contrast. The CN presents two diffraction peaks at around 13.1° and 27.3°, which are assigned to the (100) and (002) planes of carbon nitride, respectively. The former relates to the in-plane repeating tri-s-triazine units and the latter corresponds to the interplanar stacking structure [37]. The (002) diffraction peak of the B-modified samples shifted to a small diffraction angle and the peak became weaker and broader compared with CN. This indicates that the insertion of boron atoms increased the interplanar distance of the aromatic units, thereby altering the structure of carbon nitride. Meanwhile, with the increase of B content, the in-plane repeating unit (100) peak of tri-s-triazine gradually weakened and finally disappeared. The introduction of boron atoms disrupted the atomic arrangement and created defect points in the x-BCN structure, which ultimately caused ring structure distortion and decreased the crystallinity, as reported in the literature [35]. Additionally, H3BO3 could react with −NH2 in tri-s-triazine ring structure and formed the −NB(OH)2 structure [32], which passivated the original −NH2 and prevented further condensation of tri-s-triazine unit, resulting in a decrease in crystallinity. FT-IR was applied to study the composition and structure of the samples, as shown in Fig. 1(b). In the spectrum of CN, the absorption bands in the region of 1200–1700 cm−1 and 810 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching and bending vibrations of tri-s-triazine heterocycles [33], respectively. Similarly, x-BCN has a chemical skeleton as CN. However, with the introduction of B, x-BCN display a weak absorption band in these regions, indicating that the triazine ring structure was destroyed and the polymerization degree was reduced, which is consistent with the XRD results. The absorption band in 3000–3500 cm−1 was enhanced from CN to 0.30-BCN, indicating that more terminal amino groups (−NH2/−NH) or hydroxyl groups (−OH) produced with the introduction of B atoms. −NH2/−NH originated from the destroyed g-C3N4 edge, and its content increased with the decrease of g-C3N4 condensation degree. It is worth noting that these defects may provide more catalytic active sites for the adsorption and activation of CO2. Noteworthily, new peaks appearing at 1398 cm−1 and 1040 cm−1 are attributed to the stretching vibration of the B−N and B−O bonds, which confirmed the successful incorporation of B [32]. Besides, a gradually enhanced absorption peak appears at 2171 cm−1 after the incorporation of boron in CN, which is assigned to stretching modes of CN. The production of CN also prevented further polymerization of the precursor, which is helpful to the formation of more defects. To further figure out the chemical states of the successful introduction of B elements, various samples were verified by XPS measurements ( Fig. 2). The overall spectra for all catalysts are shown in Fig. 2(a), which shows three different peaks around 282, 397 and 530 eV corresponding to the carbon, nitrogen, and oxygen atoms, respectively [38]. The new peak at 189 eV in the x-BCN spectra is attributed to the B atoms [35], indicating that the B was successfully inserted into the structure of carbon nitride. The B 1 s spectrum of 0.30-BCN could be deconvoluted into three peaks at 190.9, 191.9, and 192.9 eV, which is ascribed to B−N, B−N−C, and −NB(OH)2, respectively. The corresponding binding energy of all these peaks is higher than 190.00 eV and lower than 194.00 eV, which confirms that h-hexagonal boron nitride and B2O3 were not generated [35]. Moreover, B atoms may exist in two ways in the x-BCN structure by replacing the C atoms from x-BCN network and bonding to three nitrogen atoms in the triazine or heptazine ring structure, or by reaction between H3BO3 and −NH2 on the surface of x-BCN to form −NB(OH)2. Wherein, when the C atom in the x-BCN framework was substituted by B, it might be connected to the bridged N atoms (bay B atoms) or inserted between the six-membered rings of the tri-s-triazine ring unit (corner B atoms). According to the calculation results of the atomic percentage with different B components (see Table S1), it can be concluded that bay B atoms (191.9 eV) mainly exist in the BCN network. Moreover, the percentage of B atoms associated with −NB(OH)2 gradually increased with the increase of B incorporation. It is due to the introduced B prevented further condensation of melem molecules, and resulted in more terminal amino groups (−NH2), which reacted with boric acid to generate more −NB(OH)2 groups. In the case of C 1 s XPS spectrum of CN, there are three peaks at 284.8, 286.0 and 288.2 eV belonged to the graphitic carbon (C−C), sp2 hybridized carbon (C−NH2), and triazine carbon (N−CN) in tri-s-triazine ring, respectively (Fig. 2c). Comparing to CN, C 1 s XPS of x-BCN indicates similar C chemical states. However, the C 1 s peaks of x-BCN located at around 285.6 eV contains two kinds of C atoms, corresponding to C−NH2 and C−NB(OH)2, respectively. As the replacement of the C atom by B atom, the binding energy shifted toward lower energy, which was caused by an increase in the electron cloud density on the C atoms due to the electron-giving induction effect of −NB(OH)2. Moreover, with the increase of B introduction, x-BCN shows a significant increase in the percentage of C linked to C−NB(OH)2 bonds. While the content of triazine carbon and graphitic carbon in x-BCN decreased, which led to the disruption of the crystal structure of carbon nitride. For CN, the N 1 s peak could be fitted with four peaks at binding energies of 398.7, 399.8, 401.1, and 404.4 eV (Fig. 2d). The peak at 398.7 eV is assigned to triazine skeleton nitrogen (CN−C). The peak at 399.8 eV is identified as bridge groups (C−N(−C)−C) or partially-condensed (C−N(−H)−C), and the peak at 401.1 eV is ascribed to the uncondensed primary nitrogen groups (−NH2) [39]. Besides, a broad peak at 404.4 eV is assigned to the charging effects in the carbon nitride framework. Similarly, the N 1 s spectrum of x-BCN exhibits four characteristic peaks as CN. Besides, a new peak at 399.5 eV in x-BCN is ascribed to the N−B [35], which further confirms that B atoms bind to N instead of C atoms. Table 1 summarizes the relative percentage content of nitrogen species for all catalysts. Compared to the original CN, the percentage content of CN−C in x-BCN decreased but N−B increased, which was caused by the substitution of C atoms by B in the CN framework. Whereas, the change in the content of bridged amine (C−N(−C/H)−C) and terminal amine (−NH2) was affected by the reaction between boric acid and −NH2. This reaction affected the further condensation of melem, resulted in the production of more −NH2. Part of the −NH2 could further react with boric acid to generate −NB(OH)2 groups that could activate epoxides, while the others served as the active site for activating CO2. It is worth noting that the introduction of B caused a certain impact on the electron cloud density of the different N species. For CN, the C and N atoms on the heptazine ring are bonded in sp2 hybrid orbitals, and each atom provides a p orbital with one p electron, forming a conjugated system of three ring-closed 6π electrons. The lone electron pairs on the N atom of the ring that do not participate in bonding interact with the π electrons on the heptazine ring, formed a more stable conjugated system. The result of electron homogenization could cause the charge on N transfer to the C atom partially. However, when some of the C atoms on the ring were replaced by B atoms, the large π-conjugation system of the heptazine ring was disrupted. It may be attributed that B bonded to the adjacent N via sp3 hybridized orbital, which caused a shift of the charge on the ring toward CN−C. Moreover, the N atom attached to B also formed an electron-donating p-π conjugation system with CN−C, which further caused the charge to shift toward CN−C. A higher electron cloud density is more conducive to the adsorption and activation of CO2 by triazine skeleton nitrogen (CN−C), and beneficial to the cycloaddition reaction. Elemental analysis was performed on the prepared samples, and the results are shown in Table S2. The C/N atomic ratio of CN is around 0.65 (theoretical value of g-C3N4=0.75), which implies that the sample calcined at 450 ℃ is an incomplete condensation product. With the addition of B, the C/N value gradually decreased, indicating that the degree of polymerization of x-BCN decreased. Moreover, the C content in x-BCN gradually decreased, which might resulted from more B−N structure generated in the CN framework due to the boron replacement. However, the increase in N content reconfirmed that the introduction of B prevented further condensation of melem and produced more terminal amine groups. Moreover, the C/H atomic ratio of x-BCN also gradually decreased, which is a sign of the increase of −NH2/−NB(OH)2 groups. Simultaneously, the higher O element content in x-BCN also proves the generation of −NB(OH)2, which is consistent with the analysis results of XPS. The thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out to figure out the thermal stability of CN and 0.30-BCN. As shown in Fig. S2, CN exhibits only 3.03% weight loss up to 150 ℃, which is mainly due to the evaporation of adsorbed water on the catalyst surface. Only 4.23% weight loss is observed up to 450 ℃, which confirms the high thermal stability of the ring structure. After 450 ℃, CN exhibits a rapid weight loss and the complete decomposition by 750 ℃. Whereas the weight loss of CN is slightly greater than that of 0.30-BCN at 150 ℃. Because boron has empty p-orbital in its shell that allowed it to attract water molecules, resulted in more adsorbed water on the surface of the sample after B addition. The 0.30-BCN exhibits significant weight loss between 150 and 450 ℃ in comparison to CN, and the weight loss is still ongoing after 450 ℃. It is ascribed to the insertion of boron orderly destroyed the ring structure in the CN, thereby reduced the overall stability of the x-BCN. 3.2 Morphological and textural properties studies To survey the surface morphology and relative textural properties of catalysts, SEM images ( Fig. 3) and nitrogen adsorption-desorption characterization ( Fig. 4) results of different B-modified samples were obtained. As shown in Fig. 3(a, b), pure CN is composed of a lot of amorphous fine particles, giving abundant interparticular porosity, which led to the porous structure of CN (33 m2g−1, 0.0916 cm3g−1). This special morphology was formed via NH3 and CO2 generation during the thermal treating process of CN from urea. In contrast, the x-BCN exhibits a porous layered structure, and this layered structure became more pronounced with the introduction of B, which led to a gradual increase in the BET specific surface area and pore structure. It may be related to borate melting and dehydration under high temperature conditions, as well as the reaction between boric acid and urea oligomers [39]. The enhancement in both BET surface area and pore volume exposed more active sites, which are conducive to improving the catalytic activity. However, when introduced B exceeded a critical point, the x-BCN became more solidified and the pore volume decreased (see Table S3). The major reason is that the introduction of B resulted in a distortion in the x-BCN ring structure, which led to pore collapse and more stacking of small layers. Interestingly, it can be clearly observed that small lamella curled up or stacked to form abundant orderly channels with large pore sizes (32 nm) on the surface of 0.30-BCN, which would facilitate the transport of reactants and product molecules, further improving the catalytic activity. Additionally, the energy dispersive X-ray (EDAX) spectra shown in Fig. 3(f) clearly exhibits the uniform distribution of B, C, N, and O elements in the 0.30-BCN, indicating the successful incorporation of B atoms in the CN framework. 3.3 Acidic and basic properties studies The temperature-programmed desorption (TPD) measurements were performed in order to identify and evaluate the acid-base sites on the catalysts. The NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD were employed to determine the acidic amount and basic amount of the catalysts, respectively, and the obtained curves were peak fitted. As shown in Fig. 5(a), various surface basic sites are displayed on the CO2-TPD profile of CN. According to previous reports [40], the surface basicity of CN was corresponded to the nitrogen-containing functional groups present in different forms in the catalyst structure (C−NC, −NH−, and −NH2), which resulted in three deconvoluted CO2 desorption peaks. These CO2 desorption peaks indicated the presence of weak and medium strength basic sites in the CN surface. Similarly, the CO2-TPD profile of x-BCN was deconvoluted into three peaks. Interestingly, the CO2 desorption temperature of BCN gradually increased with the introduction of B, indicating that the surface basic intensity of BCN was enhanced [35]. It was found that the content of basic site −NH2 increased firstly then decreased as the CN was modified by B. This was a result of more surface amine groups, which were generated due to the surface termination caused by the −NB(OH)2 formed from boric acid and −NH2. Subsequently, these amino groups react with the remaining boric acid again, which consumed a certain amount of −NH2. Additionally, the content of C−NC decreased with the introduction of B as a result of the destruction of heptazine ring structure and the formation of B−N bonds caused by B replacing C in the CN framework. This is consistent with the XPS results. Furthermore, the larger specific surface area of x-BCN is another reason for the enhancement in the number of basic sites because the large specific surface area exposed more activity, as confirmed by BET results. In general, the number of basic sites increased and the amount of basicity enhanced with the introduction of B. The NH3-TPD plot of CN (Fig. 5b) shows that NH3 was desorbed with a peak at around 150 ℃, corresponding to the weak adsorption of NH3, which is ascribed to acidic sites with weak strength. When the temperature was above 350 ℃, a broad desorption peak emerged, which was mainly caused by the further thermal decomposition of g-C3N4. BCN exhibited three peaks (110, 208, and 328 ℃) in lower and higher temperature regions compared to CN [35]. With the increase of B introduction, the area of NH3 desorption peak of x-BCN in the high temperature region gradually increased, which indicated the amount of basicity for x-BCN enhanced significantly as the amount of B increased. The two NH3 desorption peaks present at 208 ℃ and 328 ℃ were ascribed to the presence of the Lewis acidic sites formed by boron atoms in different chemical states, as reported in the literature [32]. Compared with CN, x-BCN had stronger acidity, which endowed the catalyst surface with acidic-basic sites and synergistically activate both CO2 and the epoxide for the cycloaddition reaction. Moreover, the amount of basicity for x-BCN enhanced significantly as the amount of B increased. Therefore, it is evident that both basic and acidic sites increased after introducing B in the CN, which is beneficial for the cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxides. 3.4 Catalytic activities The catalytic activities of CN and x-BCN were evaluated using 1, 4-butanediol diglycidyl ether (BDODGE) as the model substrate via examining the conversion of epoxide and selectivity of five-membered cyclic carbonate (5CC-BDODGE). The results are listed in Table 2. All conversion and selectivity were determined by 1H NMR characterization using toluene as an internal standard. Additionally, as a contrast, the catalytic activity of the burnt product H x B y O z of boric acid at 450 ℃ and the mixed sample of CN and H x B y O z for this reaction was also investigated. The reaction hardly occurred without catalyst participation (entry 1). The BDODGE conversion increased to 29.6% (with a 5CC-BDODGE selectivity of 92.5%) when CN was used as a catalyst. The lower conversion obtained in the case of CN was due to the presence of basic sites on its surface, which activated only CO2 molecules. After the introduction of B atoms in CN, the catalytic activity was improved further. Among all the x-BCN catalysts, 0.30-BCN obtained the highest BDODGE conversion up to 99.8%, and the best cyclic carbonate selectivity up to 99.2% at 130 °C for 20 h. The reasons are as follows. Firstly, the larger specific surface area and richer pore structure were obtained with the addition of boron in CN. The higher SBET could not only provide more catalytic active sites but also assist in the adsorption of the reactants more readily, which facilitated the contact between substrates and active groups. Besides, the larger pore size allowed better mass transport, which enabled reactant and product molecules to transfer more easily in the reaction process. Secondly, both CN and x-BCN were obtained by calcining at 450 ℃, which resulted in a lower crystallinity and polymerization degree with more edge defects. These edge defects were mainly composed of partially condensed groups such as primary amine (−NH2) groups and secondary amine (−NH−) groups. It is worth noting that CO2 molecules and epoxides could be activated by these terminal uncondensed amino groups, which was reported previously. Part of the triazine ring and bridged hydrazine in the x-BCN structure was destroyed due to the introduction of B atom, exposing more terminal amino groups, which was beneficial to the coupling of CO2 and epoxides. Furthermore, the active centers were also influenced by the introduction of B atoms. The addition of B atoms introduced Lewis acid groups such as −B(OH)2 and thus induced the formation of an acid-base duality site. Obviously, Lewis acidic and Lewis basic sites could synergistically activate the epoxides and CO2, accelerating the cycloaddition reaction. However, excessive B might harm the catalytic performance (see entry 12), since too large B addition can seriously damage the structure of CN. The mixture of CN and H x B y O z (the product of boric acid calcination at 450 ℃) was also used as a catalyst for the cycloaddition of BDODGE and CO2. Clearly, the mixture exhibited a rather poor performance giving a BDODGE conversion of 35.8% with a less than 5% 5CC-BDODGE selectivity at the same reaction conditions (Entry 4). When the reaction was carried out in the presence of H x B y O z alone, the yield was only 1.0% (Entry 3). It further indicated that the B in CN structure, as the Lewis acid site, could combine with the basic sites in the catalyst and synergistically promote the cycloaddition, which resulted in a better 5CC yield. Recyclability is a crucial standard for evaluating catalyst performance. In order to investigate the stability of the catalyst, 0.30-BCN recycling experiments were conducted by the cycloaddition of CO2 and BDODGE at 130 °C, 2.0 MPa for 20 h. After each cycle, the catalyst was recovered through filtration and centrifugation, and then thoroughly washed with acetone and anhydrous ethanol, dried, and used for the next cycle. As shown in Fig. 6, almost no decrease was detected in the conversion of BDODGE and the selectivity of 5CC-BDODGE after 5 cycles, indicating that the catalyst has superior stability. In addition, the structure of the recycled catalyst was also characterized to elucidate the mechanism for maintaining good stability. XRD patterns and FT-IR spectra of 0.30-BCN before and after use for five runs were shown in Fig. S4 (a, b), respectively. In the XRD patterns (Fig. S4a), the used BGCN05 resembled the fresh 0.30-BCN, indicating the catalyst maintained stability after recycling. The FT-IR shows that a new absorption peak appeared at 1785 cm−1 on the recycled catalyst, which is attributed to the residual macromolecular product cyclic carbonate in the catalyst sample. Furthermore, in the TGA curves (Fig. S4c), a new weight loss peak was found in the recovered 0.30-BCN, which was attributed to the mass loss of residual cyclic carbonates in the catalyst. In general, 0.30-BCN presented excellent catalytic performance due to its multiple active sites on the surface. Since 0.30-BCN owns superior catalytic performance among all catalysts, the optimal reaction condition for CO2 cycloaddition was further studied using 0.30-BCN as the catalyst, as shown in Fig. S5. The 5CC-BDODGE yield was positively correlated with the temperature in the range of 110–140 ℃ (Fig. S5a). Obviously, with the temperature raised from 110 to 140 ℃, the 5CC-BDODGE yield remarkably increased from 47.5% to 99.7%, which is due to the increased effective collision between catalyst and reactant with the increase of temperature. When the temperature was 130 ℃, the 5CC-BDODGE yield reached 99%. However, as the temperature further increased to 140 ℃, the 5CC-BDODGE yield slightly increased. Therefore, 130 ℃ was considered the appropriate reaction temperature. The catalytic results obtained at different reaction times are shown in Fig. S5b. With prolonging the reaction time, gradual enhancement in the BDODGE conversion was obtained. From the curve, it can be observed that BDODGE conversion almost linearly increased in the first 15 hours, then slowly risen reaching 99.8% after the next 5 hours, and the 5CC-BDODGE selectivity remained above 98%. Additionally, catalytic reactions were found to be insensitive to the pressure of CO2. A higher BDODGE yield was obtained, both in the low or high pressure, which may be related to the properties of large molecule bifunctional epoxies themselves. Optimizing the reaction conditions, it has been demonstrated that 0.30-BCN could efficiently catalyze CO2 cycloaddition reaction under mild conditions. Subsequently, the suitability of 0.30-BCN catalyst for other epoxides was also investigated and the results were displayed in Fig. 7. It is found that 0.30-BCN shows high catalytic activity for all epoxides. Obviously, the activity of ECH is superior to other mono-functional epoxides, due to the Cl– in ECH structure. In the reaction process, the Cl anion released by ECH served as a nucleophilic agent to promote the ring opening of epoxides, thus facilitating the cycloaddition reaction. The better conversion (90.7%) was achieved when styrene oxide was used. It might be ascribed to phenyl-induced changes in the electron cloud of the epoxy group, making the epoxy group more vulnerable to attack by nucleophiles. Additionally, the catalytic activity of bifunctional epoxides (EDODGE, NPODGE, BDODGE, HDODGE) was found to be higher than mono-functional epoxide (PO, ECH, SO), which related to the O atom from the ether bond of glycidol ether. The O atom, as an electron-withdrawing group with high electronegativity, could strongly attract the electron cloud adjacent to the epoxy group, which made it easier to open the ring during the attack of nucleophiles. For the epoxide (such as PO) without such an electronegative structure, it showed a lower yield (78.7%). Also, the steric hindrance also affected the conversion of epoxide. For example, the conversion of NPODGE is lower than that of other bisepoxides. Therefore, it is reasonable to expect that 0.30-BCN would be a promising catalyst for the synthesis of cyclic carbonates and potential industrial application because of its high catalytic activity and suitability for various epoxides. The catalytic performance of several g-C3N4-based catalysts reported in the cycloaddition reaction of CO2 and SO are summarized in Table S4. Metallic Zn-doped g-C3N4 catalysts such as 2.0Zn@g-C3N4-550 [41], Zn-CN/C [42], ZnBr2/g-C3N4 [33], and 5ZnO2/g-C3N4-400 [43] presented excellent catalytic activity in the cycloaddition reactions of CO2 and SO. Meanwhile, some metal-free g-C3N4-based catalysts have also shown efficient catalytic performance for CO2 cycloaddition, such as B-doped [35], P and B co-doped [44], SBA-15-loaded [32], K,B-CN-4 [45]and modified by carboxyl or other functional groups [29] g-C3N4-based catalysts. Although the previous catalysts have realized effective conversion of CO2 into SC, most of them still needed a co-catalyst or solvent. In comparison with the catalysts listed above, the metal-free 0.30-BCN developed in a simple method exhibited excellent catalytic activity and could achieve comparable or higher product yield for the CO2 cycloaddition without any solvent and co-catalyst. 3.5 Reaction mechanism Based on the above discussions and related literature [26,46,47], a possible mechanism for the coupling reaction of CO2 with epoxides over 0.30-BCN was proposed and illustrated in Scheme 4. Firstly, the −NH2, −NH− and acidic −B(OH)2 sites in catalyst structure, as hydrogen bond donors [46,47], formed hydrogen bonds with O atom of epoxide, which activated the epoxides to undergo the CO2 cycloaddition. Meanwhile, the N-containing groups served as Lewis bases to activate CO2 and formed carbamate salt simultaneously. Subsequently, tertiary amine conducted a nucleophilic attack on the less sterically hindered β-carbon atom of the activated epoxide and enabled the ring-opening of epoxides, forming an intermediate for oxygen-negative ions. After that, a new linear alkyl carbonate compound was generated due to the nucleophilic attack of oxygen anion on carbamate salt. Ultimately, the subsequent intermediate formed the cyclic carbonate after intramolecular ring closure and regenerated the catalyst simultaneously. It was worth noting that the synergetic effect of both acidic sites (derived from boron atoms) and basic sites (derived from nitrogen atoms) presented on BCN catalysts could activate CO2 and epoxide simultaneously, thus promoted the reaction significantly. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, a series of metal-free carbon nitrides (x-BCN) with varying boron content were successfully prepared via thermal condensation of urea and boric acid at 450 ℃. As a catalyst for CO2 cycloaddition with epoxides, 0.30-BCN exhibited a high 5CC-BDODGE yield (99%) and excellent stability in the absence of solvent and co-catalyst. It was found that a low crystallinity and polymerization degree of CN with more edge defects (−NH2) was obtained at lower preparation temperature. These edge defects caused by incomplete condensation of carbon nitride were considered active sites for CO2 activation. Moreover, boron hydroxyl groups (−B(OH)2) were formed in the catalyst by introduced B atom, which could activate epoxide. CO2 and epoxide could be co-activated on the catalyst surface, which further promoted the cycloaddition due to the existence of acid-base duality. Additionally, the increase in surface area of x-BCN was another important factor in achieving its excellent catalytic performance. In summary, the multi-synergistic effects of edge defects (−NH2, −NH−), N atoms (CN−C) of the s-triazine skeleton unit, boron hydroxyl groups (−B(OH)2), and high specific surface area maximized the catalytic potential of x-BCN for CO2 cycloaddition. In addition, a possible multi-synergetic mechanism for CO2 cycloaddition was put forward. Considering the high catalytic activity, thermal stability, and good recoverability, 0.30-BCN is expected to be an efficient heterogeneous catalyst in the utilization of CO2 for the synthesis of cyclic carbonate. coredata.dc:description: The cycloaddition of CO2 and epoxide is regarded as an eco-friendly, sustainable, and promising way to utilize CO2. However, it is crucial to design and prepare efficient and low-cost catalysts for this reaction. Herein, through controlling condensation temperature, a series of boron modified urea-derived g-C3N4 (x-BCN) were prepared. Notably, more edge defect (−NH2/−NH−) formed at low roasting temperatures and both basic and acidic sites increased after introducing B. 0.30-BCN exhibited superior catalytic performance for cycloaddition of CO2 with 1, 4-butanediol diglycidyl ether and 99% cyclic carbonate yield was acquired at 130 ℃, 2.0 MPa after 20 h reacting. Additionally, 0.30-BCN showed outstanding recyclability and substrate adaptability. The synergistic effects of edge defects, rich mesoporous structure and Lewis acid-base sites were conductive to promoting CO2 cycloaddition. Moreover, a possible multi-synergetic mechanism was proposed. An originality option was provided for preparing a simple, eco-friendly, and efficient metal-free catalyst for practical CO2 fixation.
coredata.dc:title: A new boron modified carbon nitride metal-free catalyst for the cycloaddition of CO2 and bisepoxides
